awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Scalable Photonic Crystal Fabrication for Mesoscale Fuel-to-Electricity Conversion
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to commercialize a novel technology that enables compact, efficient, silent, reliable, and fuel-flexible power generation. Existing power solutions can lack endurance, reliability, and portability and often generate harmful emissions; or they are prohibitively expensive or incompatible with existing fuels and distribution infrastructure.  The power generation platform developed in this project has the potential to be a key enabling technology for the future rapid growth of commercial drone applications, which currently are often limited by the performance of lithium ion batteries. Drones are expected to make an impact across numerous industries including transport and delivery, power and utilities, telecommunications, and remote sensing. Additionally, this power generation technology can benefit industrial internet of things applications.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a novel power source that is easily portable and is compatible with existing fuel infrastructure. This project develops a system that converts most fuels to electricity via light; combustion heats a nanophotonic material to incandescence and the resulting light drives photovoltaic cells. The nanophotonic material is engineered to be spectrally matched to the photovoltaic cells, enabling efficient conversion. This technology can increase the endurance of drones or other systems up to ten times over batteries alone. This work is focused on cost reduction through new material development. The specific research objectives are to demonstrate a low-cost and scalable process for the nanophotonic material and photovoltaic cell while maintaining high performance, and then integrate and pilot the low cost system. Successful completion of these objectives will enable this technology to translate to drone applications with a compelling need for long-lasting portable power.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Mesodyne is developing a game-changing compact, silent, multi-fuel, power generator that enables up to 10X increase in runtime over batteries for smaller drones, medical equipment, remote sensors, soldiers, emergency personnel and more. Mesodyne's LightCell power generator is a platform technology benefiting applications where performance is limited by battery weight or where all other sources of power (grid, solar, wind, etc.) are not available or practical. 

Our customer discovery process revealed a strong product-market fit across various industries. We found that in remote areas without grid access, establishing transmission lines is costly, and solar/wind power is unreliable. Existing solutions are often large and permanent, making them unsuitable for these locations. Our LightCell generator offers a unique solution. In Antarctica, it supports researchers by powering remote sensors for extended periods, even without sunlight. In the oil and gas sector, it enhances the reliability of remote wellpads and pipelines. Additionally, our generator benefits remote communities lacking reliable power and aids disaster relief efforts. The growing emphasis on energy independence and infrastructure resilience further validates the demand for the LightCell technology as a dependable, portable, efficient power source operating on any fuel available.

The specific application where we found the most traction and market pull was the small unmanned systems market. Specifically, manufacturers of smaller UASs (under 55 pounds) are seeking to increase the range and endurance of their drones, which is currently limited by available battery technologies. Our solution offers the potential to extend drone range, leading to more efficient UAS employment, reducing the required number of platforms, and minimizing airspace congestion.

In Phase I, we developed a scalable photonic crystal substrate preparation process from commercial foils using a novel high-throughput process. We nanofabricated the photonic crystal over the large flexible substrate using interference lithography and traditional semiconductor manufacturing tools. We integrated the photonic crystal with a cylindrical microcombustor by diffusion brazing. We modeled the performance enhancements of a UAS powered by our generator.

In Phase II, we built an initial working prototype of the LightCell generator incorporating our novel photonic crystal fabrication process, as well as extensive work developing two types of new low bandgap photovoltaic cells with improved performance. This prototype was demonstrated as a standalone generator but paves the way for a drone range extender for the commercial UAS market. This work is also critical in commercializing thermophotovoltaics for energy conversion applications that require large areas at relatively low costs include thermophotovoltaic energy storage, selective solar absorbers, solar thermal systems, radiative cooling systems, and more.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Veronika Stelmakh
